text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Isaac Selby Tomney

2. Your address: Assiniboia, Sask.

3. Date: August 15, 1952

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Parry Sound, Muskoka Dist., Ontario, Canada

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Joel Tomney - Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): August 23rd, 1900

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.: Drayton and Hamilton, Ontario

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.): 20 years old

9. What were your reasons for coming West?: Had an uncle living in Western Canada (Assiniboia, Sask.) and decided to come West striking we could better ourselves Bought 1/2 section of C.P.R. land at $3.00 an acre and 1/4 mile Hudson Bay Land 2 yrs. later at $8.00 an acre.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?): Through Uncle alone mentioned
1. Your full name: Emery Isaac Selby

2. Your address: Assiniboia, Saskatchewan

3. Date: August 15, 1957

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Parry Sound, Muskoka District, Ontario, Canada

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Frank Fleming - Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): August 29, 1900

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Brantford and Hamilton, Ontario

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you did not come at all or you may use "I was a small child")

"I was in my teens"

9. What were your personal or family reasons for coming West?

"We all had been living in Western Canada (Muskoka, South) and decided to come West instead of going further afield and try to find a better life by land or sea."

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Hollywood or government information?)

"Through uncle always mentioned."
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   Traveled with family (father, mother, two brothers and sister).

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   C.P.R.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   On arrival for Sunday School lecture in Hamilton, Ont., Wempy, a former Sunday School teacher, met us at the train station and took us to his boarding house for breakfast. We almost missed the train getting back.
   Also on our train was a car of Doukhobors from Russia. I walked through the car and noticed that the women wore high Walker boots & their knees.
   Tonight and that we changed trains at North Bay from First Class to the old Colonist cars with flat seats.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   At the home of my uncle, by marriage, and aunt, living 8 miles North, and 1 mile West of Moose Jaw, Saskatchewan.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   8 miles North and 1 mile West of Moose Jaw.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   I homesteaded at Assiniboia September 9, 1908 - land being located 1 mile North of the present town of Assiniboia.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
   Worked in a factory after leaving school, and before coming West. After coming West took up farming.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

13. What means of transportation did you use?

C. P. R.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, mishaps or other excitement)

On arriving at Edmonton we traveled North with Hamilton and Mr. Herring

We camped at the Hill and went over to the railway

We came from Calgary to Edmonton and remained there for two weeks

Then we traveled through the West and arrived in Regina

There were high prairies and rolling hills and railway

The weather was very hot and that was challenging and cruel

From there we traveled to the Red River Colony and went

Living 8 miles North and 1 mile West of Broom Jaw

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

8 acres North and 1 mile West of Broom Jaw

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

I homesteaded at Cameron's Creek, Saskatchewan

In 1908 I moved to the Southside

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Worked in a factory after learning railroad work and before starting to work up farming.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   Occasionally.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date
    and place of marriage.
   Married Margaret Anna Matheson in 1906 at Moose Jaw, Sask.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place
    to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West
    tell when they came and where they settled.
   As mentioned previously, the family came together.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stand out in your
    memory which you would like to record?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church,
    visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
   Used to travel 1/2 mile to church, in school house in a wagon. After moving to Assiniboia, and before
   the railroad came through, had to haul grain to Moose Jaw, a distance of 50 miles, and bring
   back supplies such as coal and flour, etc. A round trip would take approx. five days
   by team and wagon.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Occasionally.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Married Mr. H. W. Wilson in 1906 at

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? It was a place to settle?

As mentioned previously, the family came together.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience or pioneer days that stand out in your memory which you would like to recount?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Had a horse & buggy & school in school town in a wagon. Often visited relatives & friends by horse & buggy. The railroad came first, then the stage coach. To Prairies, gas, a little bit of road, and then by train. Back again, and on road and plains, & by train. By horse & buggy, and sometimes by train.
One experience I might record was the time in the year 1910, that I drove Willow Bunch for the doctor for one of my neighbors. Willow Bunch was one of the first settlements in the southern part of Saskatchewan, and was thirty miles from my homestead. I started out right after dinner, about one o'clock, with a horse and buggy. The neighbor for whom I was making the trip insisted that I take his horse and buggy. I arrived at Willow Bunch around five o'clock in the afternoon.

On arrival, I fed my horse but she didn't seem to want to eat. When the doctor arrived in from the country, he gave me a bottle of medicine to take back, saying he didn't think he could make a trip back then. I started for home, and after having gone two or three miles, I noticed the horse didn't want to travel. About that time I met a man along the trail, with a yoke of oxen. After talking to him a few minutes, and telling him my difficulties, he advised me to go on a mile or two up the road where I would find a shack. I continued on my way, and arrived at an old sod shack about 10' x 12'. When I drove up to the door a man and woman came out, who happened to be early French settlers that couldn't speak English. To make them understand what my trouble was (that my horse was sick), I pointed to my mouth with my finger, and then to the horse. The man went in the shack and came out with a small box of ordinary table salt. While he was handing the salt to me, the horse started to stagger, so I dropped the traces and ran the buggy back - then the horse dropped dead. So here I was, still twenty-five miles from home, my horse dead, and nowhere to stay all night.

I started out to walk, and had gone probably a couple of miles when I noticed a team and buggy coming behind, which turned out to be the doctor from Willow Bunch. He said he would come up and see the sick neighbor, so gave me a lift on home.

Naturally, I had to go back for my buggy and harness, so leaving home next morning around eight o'clock, with a team and wagon, I arrived at my destination around noon. In driving up to the sod shack again, I saw a man and woman come out of the door; each with a large butcher knife about a foot long. They made signs at me which I took to mean they wanted my permission to skin the dead animal. I gave them the nod to go ahead. Then after feeding my team, and eating my lunch, I decided to watch them. After skinning the horse, and spreading the skin on the ground, they cut the tenderloin off one side of the back, rolled the carcass over and cut the tenderloin off the other side. They then placed both pieces on the skin, and dragged it over to the shack, and this I presumed they planned on using for food.

I decided then it was about time to start for home, so I hitched up my team, tied the buggy on behind, and started down the road - twenty-five miles to go. I arrived home around supper time, and figured I had had quite an experience.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

Come with the idea of staying permanently.
One experience I might record was the time in the year 1910 that I drove to Willow Bunch for the doctor for one of my neighbors. Willow Bunch was one of the first settlements in the southern part of the district, and was thirty miles from my homestead.

I started out right after dinner, and was thirty-five miles from my horse and buggy. The neighbor for whom I was making the trip insisted that I take his horse and buggy, so when I arrived at Willow Bunch around five o'clock in the afternoon.

On arrival, I fed my horse but she didn't seem to want to eat. When the doctor arrived in from the country he gave me a bottle of medicine to take back, saying he didn't think I could make a trip back then. I started for home and after having gone two or three miles, I noticed the horse didn't want to travel any further. After talking to him a few minutes and telling him my difficulties, he advised me to go on a mile or two up the road where I would find a shock. I continued on my way, and arrived at an old sod shack about ten o'clock. When I drove up to the door a man and woman came out, who happened to be early French settlers that couldn't speak English, to make them understand what my trouble was (that my horse was sick), I pointed to my mouth with my finger and then to the horse. The man went into the shack and came out with a small box and ordinary table salt. While he was standing there, I salted the horse's back - then the horse dropped dead. So here I was, still twenty-five miles from home, my horse dead, and nowhere to stay all night.

I started out to walk, and had gone probably a couple of miles when I noticed a team and buggy coming behind, which turned out to be the doctor from Willow Bunch. He gave me a lift on home.

Naturally I had to go back for my buggy and harness, so leaving home next morning around eight o'clock, with a team and wagon, I arrived at Willow Bunch again. I saw a man and woman close our of the door, each with a large butcher knife about a foot long. They made signs at me which I took to mean they wanted my permission after feeling my veins, and appealing to them, I decided to wash them off, cut the tendon on one side of the neck, pull out the head over, peel out the inner skin of the other side, they then patted both fleas on the skin, and charged me over to the shack, and said I presumed they planned on cooking for food.

I hitched up my team, tied the buggy behind and started down the road - driving five miles to go. I arrived home around supper time and figured I had had quite an experience.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

Come will be very glad to permanent
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   1913 or 1914, in Assiniboia.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   Didn't own a car prior to 1914.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Located at Leamill - which was just a P.O. and
   every store on the farm. I think the line was adjusted
   there before land was purchased.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing,
   better means of travel, etc.)
   Railway came through in 1912 and the town of
   Assiniboia came into being.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Once a month.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly
   on Saturdays?
   When the town of Assiniboia opened up
   in 1912.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?
   What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of
   your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of
   purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   1914 or 1915, Company - Assiniboia Rural.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying
   permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you
   make this decision?
   Came with the idea of staying permanently.
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1913 or 1914.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What makes?

27. Was your trading center? How far from your home?

28. Did you continue to ride there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns, etc.)

29. How often did you shop in the early days? Once a month.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

Come and be a part of history permanently.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?
   Answer: Half dozen families moved from Assiniboia, and some returned later.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1) & (2), (3).

   Our water supply for Assiniboia came from a dam at Eldon, constructed by the North and was recently named the J.B. Smith dam after J.B. Smith, Liberal Member for the constituency at the time dam was built.
5. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1920? If so, why?

35. Did any members of your family attend school in the 1920s? If so, did they return?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organization, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were affiliated with any organization in the district, mention it here, giving dates whenever possible (such as joining the Elks, automobile club, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, townships, streets, hills, etc.)

(1) Name of place (2) Person responsible (3) Reason for name (4) Date of name change (5) Current name

Our family attended the school by the river and moved nearby around the 19th and 20th century.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying? .......

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon? ....... (indicate your preference, if any) ..................

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

I would just like to say that while I was visiting my daughters in Regina this summer she helped me fill this out.

J. J. Emery

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here:

Mrs. Florence Baker
2038 Thornton Ave.,
Regina, Wisconsin, U.S.A.
6.

39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?

(Indicate your preference, if any)

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you moved here?

My family forever
Oct 23/52

Dear Sir,

I am today returning those books you sent me some time ago regarding the holy selling of prisoners, only I didn't get them back sooner but just kept putting it off. However, I was down visiting my daughter, Miss Betsy, at Berea, Ohio last month, and she gave me a helping hand, and so she is a telegrapher she helped out the local call answering. (sic)

I had in my early housekeeping days.

Yours Truly,

[Signature]

Sara S. Conley
October 23/54

To Mr. Secretary,

I am writing to you in response to your request for information regarding the current situation in Assiniboia. I have been informed by Mr. Smith, who is currently serving as the Assiniboia County Commissioner, that the county is experiencing a shortage of funds due to the recent drought conditions.

Mr. Smith has also mentioned that the county is in need of additional support from the provincial government to address these challenges. I urge you to consider providing assistance to ensure the well-being of the citizens of Assiniboia.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

[Signature]

Emery Isaac Selby
